body.text: This module summarises key clinical observations that guide urgent decision making for cardiopulmonary emergencies. Pay attention to the patterns that link symptoms, laboratory values, and imaging.
When you read the scenario, identify the organ system involved, recall the dominant physiology, and reason through the differential before selecting the response.

questions.title: Chest pain in the emergency department
questions.context: A 58-year-old man presents with substernal chest pain and diaphoresis that started 45 minutes ago. His ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF.
questions.stem: Which coronary artery is most likely occluded?
questions.explanation: Inferior ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF most commonly reflect an occlusion of the right coronary artery, which supplies the inferior wall of the left ventricle.

questions.title: Renal physiology checkpoint
questions.context: A nephron segment reabsorbs about 65% of the filtered sodium and water and has leaky tight junctions. It is also the site of bulk reabsorption of glucose and amino acids.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Thin descending limb of the loop of Henle

choices.label: C
choices.text: Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation: The proximal convoluted tubule reabsorbs the majority of filtered sodium, water, glucose, and amino acids through its leaky tight junctions, making it the best match for this description.

questions.title: Acid–base interpretation
questions.context: Arterial blood gas results show pH 7.28, PaCO2 55 mm Hg, and HCO3- 25 mEq/L.
questions.explanation: The elevated PaCO2 with an acidic pH and near-normal bicarbonate is most consistent with a primary respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation.
